segments.text: What was your background situation at the time you joined the church, and how do you think it affected your decision to join?
At the time that I joined, I was a sophomore in college at Kansas State University.
I first met a group of three people who identified themselves as members of a unified family.

In November of 1972, they just invited me over to have a meal with them and to talk with some of their ideas about engendering cooperation between different denominations and working for social change.
Well, it happened to hit me in a very sensitive spot.
I had gone to Kansas State University in the midst of a rather difficult decision about whether I would be involved with war or not and had decided to be a conscientious objector.
I was very serious about faith matters.
I'd even changed churches while I was a senior in high school in order to become involved in a church that had peace ideals.
I was involved with student government and was studying English to be an English as a second language teacher because I felt a very strong sense of social responsibility.
Also, on a personal level, I had experienced and did continue to experience through this sophomore year a large number of disappointments with friends, with a girlfriend I was involved with.
And also with classes, professors.
It was just a very difficult year as a sophomore year often is.
How do you think that affected your decision to join the church?
Well, I don't think that I would have been so... Well, of course, you have to remember the time this was.
People were not talking about a cult, and nobody knew anything about the Unification Church.
I didn't find out that the name of it was Unification Church until April when I joined, as a matter of fact.
But that didn't make any difference to me then anyway, because nobody knew anything about it at that point in the early 70s in Kansas.
I think that they had been going on the coast for a while, and a few people knew, but...
I still think, though, that there were a lot of things about the group that I found very strange.
Some of their theological ideas I just sort of brushed off as being off the wall, but they were nice people, and I had worked with people with whom I had differences before.

But I don't think I would have been so willing to make the kind of commitment that I made to them had I not been in a situation where I just desperately needed friendship, some people who were planning to be consistent, and also some structure in my life.
I had a lot of difficult decisions to make and nobody really helped me make them.

I had kind of cut myself adrift from my family in a number of different ways, not that we had always been that close, but particularly with my decision to be a CO, my father, who had been in both the Army and the Air Force, was not at all happy about that, as you can well imagine.
And so I had a hard time drawing on people.
And some of the people who I depended on
I had fallen out of my life.
I had grown close to a girl during high school, but we were unable to make things work out on weekends to be able to spend time together, so that relationship sort of dwindled.
The president of the student body and I became very close friends and decided to move in together during the sophomore year.
And he had a house that he was renting and one of his roommates had moved out, so I moved in at semester break.
Well, he left school.
of his responsibilities and left me with a house to rent.
So there were just a lot of very difficult things happening.
I do think that it would have been much less likely that I would have gotten involved as a member had I been at a more stable position in life.
Do you think there are common personality traits or common past experiences among Unification Church members?
That's an interesting question.
I don't really think that you would say common personality traits.
in that you would find all kinds of people in Unification Church.
By far, the majority of the members were young, that is to say, college age to early 30s, white middle class.
I would say there was probably a fairly large number of Roman Catholics involved in relationship to the population of the United States, but that's just a guess.
I mean, that's a pure guess.
I have no data on that at all.
Very low percentage of minorities, almost no blacks at all, very few Hispanics.
Very few people from either lower income groups or the very, very wealthy.
Again, that's sort of a guess.
The lower income groups I would say pretty definitely.
Different groups of this type, fringe groups that are often identified as cults, such as the Children of God and the Hare Krishna movement, seem to exhibit sort of the same kind of profile.
Other groups, like the Jim Jones People's Temple, seem to draw on a different group.
For them, it was mostly middle-aged and older blacks.
So, you know, different groups seem to attract different kinds of individuals in terms of age groups and that sort of thing.
But as far as personality, I would hesitate to say.
I think that everybody has the propensity or the capacity for making
sort of fanatical commitments.
I mean, we all need something that we can really believe in, I think, and something that we can commit ourselves to.
We all need to feel like we're right and we're doing something good.
And I think that's a human trait and not necessarily just a personality trait of some people.
I think that's a need that we all have, and that's what the Church draws on to a great degree.
When church members first approached you, did they reveal affiliation with Moon?
Or how long were you acquainted with them before they revealed that they were affiliated with Moon?
Well, the name Sun Myung Moon didn't mean anything to me at that time.
I didn't know anything about him.
But no, they didn't talk about it at all until I got ready to join the group, which was in April.
So from November to April, five or six months, however long that is.
I did not know that it was the Unification Church.
Again, that name didn't mean anything to me.
I probably would have liked it, as a matter of fact.
But as far as I knew, it was called the Unified Family, and that's all I knew.
And what did they declare their beliefs to be?
Initially, they did not declare that they had an independent theology.

It was more like this is an ecumenical organization, which I assumed, and which many people did assume, and they wanted you to assume, you know, they led you to assume, that it was a group that rather than having independent ideas, was simply an organization with service ideals.
And that was very attractive to me.
As time went on, they said we should come over to our lecture series.
And I realized that they did have a specific theology.
And some of the ideas in the theology really took me aback.
I was just really shocked.
The idea that the Fall of Man was essentially a sexual act.
I didn't want to laugh, but I found it pretty bizarre.
And frankly, I think the ramifications of that were at some level sort of evident to me when they first told me that.
I thought, gee, you could really get the real warped view of the world with that kind of an idea.
Or I shouldn't say warped.
That shows my own bias.
But I just thought that would really affect your world view in an extreme way.
And that was the point where I said, well, I've worked with people with whom I had differences before, who had different opinions.
So it didn't really upset me that much.
But it was a month or so after I'd first met them.
I should tell you,
Oh, I probably didn't actually go out to the center until December when we got past finals.
I was a little bit freer in terms of time, and I think I saw them once, maybe twice before January.
And then I didn't see them again for a couple of months.
I got back into the swing of school and just didn't make time to go out there.
I didn't feel the tug that strongly.
They sent food home with me, which was a good ploy to use with a male who was living on his own.
But...
I don't think I really heard any of the lectures until probably March.
Would you say that the social responsibility was your initial attraction to the group?
Well, yeah, also there was a strong personal attraction in that
The people were obviously very dedicated and obviously willing to make a lot of sacrifices.
They lived very simply and that was attractive to me.
They obviously had an interest in me.

One of the girls in the group I found rather cute and interesting, although I don't think a person who I would have spent a lot of time with, but I felt like our personalities had a lot in common, and I would have enjoyed getting to know her better.
The other two, not so much, but...
Obviously it was a combination of personal and ideological reasons.
How were you first approached by members of the church?
I was in the cafeteria at K-State.
As a church member, you develop an ability through hours and days and weeks and months of attempting to make solicitations and proselytizations.
You develop a sense for who is going to be accessible.
and they sense that I would be right away.
I think there's a number of things involved with that.
I'm willing to go up to people and make friends, you know, walk up and make contacts.
I'm open to new things.
A fairly...
sensitive, emotional person.
And I think that ends up what the person's emotional state, whether they're at a pretty stable place going along day to day, or whether they're in a state of emotional flux, and they're up and down.
And experiencing a lot of emotion makes a lot of difference in terms of how suggestible people are.
And I was probably pretty evidently at a point of some emotional flux at that time.
I'm sure they picked up on that as well.
The church members don't end up verbalizing a lot of that stuff.
Some of them do.
Some of them are more aware of it than others.
I think the ones who are the best at it, sensitive and intuitive level, they don't even think about it.
They know.
During those first few contacts, were you ever exposed to the church's views on communism?
Not at all.
I wasn't particularly pro or anti-communist, so it wouldn't have made much difference.
But no, they were careful not to talk about...
I think that they may have mentioned it, but they certainly didn't dwell on it.
And that didn't end up being a big thing one way or the other for me.
They really talked...
I mean, it was like a whole other group once I became involved.
There was just so little that they actually told me about the group.
Because there is such a superstructure of ideology and theology and strange ideas and reading of the speeches of Moon and all that kind of stuff.
There's a great deal of that that goes on in the group.
But that's all hidden from the outside.
And there's an extremely intense interpersonal structure that every individual has his own personal leader to whom he or she is responsible.
And that string goes all the way up to moon in a very intense fashion.
And there's a lot of interpersonal manipulation that goes on all the way up.
The idea of being loyal is an extremely high ideal and an effective means of control.
But that's also hidden.
You don't see any of that kind of stuff.
It's just sort of like, well, they go to talk to different churches and have wonderful ideals.
And it's not until you become involved that you find out that the major activities for the group are
fundraising, proselytizing, and trying to expand their political influence in terms of the ideology.
That's really all that gets done.
And the leadership of the church is very aware of that.
I was at a speech given by one of the Japanese leaders in Japan.
He talked about that.
Those are the three main things.
They talk about building the heavenly kingdom on a basis of a...
of example, that by establishing perfect families that are in harmony with God, then they're going to demonstrate how the world is supposed to be.
So they do believe that they're in the process of building this kind of a kingdom and that sort of thing.
And there are people who join the group and quit drugs because of it or that kind of stuff.
So they're involved with drug rehabilitation.
That's the kind of thinking that goes on.
The kind of social service that they're involved in is proselytizing and fundraising.
So after you first met those first few church members, what was the first activity that you went to or group meeting?
Well, there were only three people in the center, only three people in the state of Kansas who were involved in the church at that time when I first met them.
And I went over and just had a meal with them.
And they sang some songs, which I found pretty crazy.
But as a musician, music is fun.
I think that I was given lectures individually.
As I recall, they would actually sit down and give the lectures to me on a one-to-one basis later in the spring.
But the first couple times that I saw them, I just went over and had lunch with them.
Later on, after I...
I think all of the lectures that I attended were on a personal, individual, under one basis.
Now that's of course atypical.
That's not at all typical for the way most people join.
But after that, the first group activities I was involved in was as a member, being involved in the church prayer meetings and stuff like that.
What is the typical way that most people become involved then?
I think in terms of where most people are when they're approached, most people who join the group have fallen into the category of being at a
more emotional point of their life.
They're in situations where maybe they've had some great joy, they've just gotten married, or they've just moved into a new community, or maybe they've gone away to college.
And these kinds of periods of upheaval can last for years.
A person who's in college, it just hardly ever ends.
But in any event, being in an emotional time of life, one tends to be somewhat less reasoned and connected to one's surroundings.
You're going more on your own feelings.
And a college student is, of course, the most unconnected person in our society, except maybe for the hobo.
So there's that sort of thing.

And what the church ordinarily does is meets these people on the street or on the college campus, invites them to a dinner and a lecture on some topic that they think will be of interest to people who are in that demographic area.

So that is to say, when they're talking to people on the Berkeley campus, they're going to be approaching them somewhat differently than they will be when they're at the K-State campus, for example, or in the train station in Oklahoma City.
But they try to aim for something that is a sort of low common denominator and yet still is going to interest people who may be susceptible.
So they're not going to be as likely to go after a person who's
basically agnostic, happily married, with a good, secure job with Donald Lynch.
They're going after people who have some interest in different kinds of religious ideas and ideals, and people to whom an ideal city project might be interesting, or that sort of thing.
They invite them over to a dinner and a lecture.
They will deliver a lecture on the ideal family or the ideal world, using things that come from Christian theology and also from Buddhism.
Pretty innocuous.
somewhat bland, but very fervent.
And the room in which they have the lecture, there will be many members of the church there.
They will try to have as many members per new person as possible.
About a one-to-one ratio is ideal.
But there are times when they may have more new people than they have members.
But in those instances, it's very hard for them to control the energy in the room and control the atmosphere.
Then that's what they really want to do.
They will sing songs.
They may have prayers.
It depends.
San Francisco, they probably won't.
But in Des Moines, they will, definitely.
Or in Dallas.
And then after that they'll invite them to go to a weekend workshop.
And the fee, if any, will be minimal.
At the weekend workshop, they will receive the same introductory lecture with somewhat more elaboration.
And then they'll go through the whole series of the divine principle to greater or lesser detail, depending on the situation and the lecturer.
And at the end of that, the people who are interested, the lectures are set up in such a way that they have real emotional impact.
psychological hooks.
Anyway, at the end of the weekend lecture series, and they'll invite them to go to a week-long lecture series.
And the people who go to the week-long lecture series, it's a pretty high percentage of people joining.
And some people even join after a weekend.
But the people who go to the...
If you can get them away from their home for a week to work together and to sing together and, you know, the very intense...
working on people on a one-to-one basis with a great deal of love and personal interest.
So it's pretty effective.

I should talk a little about the way the lecture series is structured because the ideas in and of themselves, I think again, seem probably rather innocuous and a little bit all kind of quirky and funny, but certainly not malignant.
The thing is, is that the way the lecture series is delivered and organized, it makes people feel personal responsibility.
It's designed to make people feel personal responsibility for the state of the world.
The first lecture is one that, as I said, talks about the ideal world, the ideal family that got it intended in the beginning.

And the second lecture speaks about the fall of man, which is identified as being, and with some rather interesting proof texting and rather convoluted reasoning, identifies the fall of man as essentially being a physical relationship or spiritual relationship, in any event a sexual one, which was premature.
And since it was premature before the individuals had fully developed on an individual basis, they established a dependency which should not have existed for ideal love.
It was a needing neurotic kind of love that they became involved in.

And because of that, they say, then true parents, perfect parents who can give love unconditionally never developed because the children born out of that first experience were never given that kind of love themselves.
So there was this endless cycle of...
Parents who didn't know fully how to love giving birth to children who also didn't learn it.
And the thing that this does is that it plugs into everyone's own anxieties and feelings of guilt about desires for premarital sex.
which is a big guilt thing in our society.
And as the lecture series goes on, they talk about how the Jews failed to unite with Christ, and a lot of the ideas of the Christology are very strange, and they lose a lot of Christians there.
And some of the lecturers really soft-pedal a lot of that stuff.

But when they start talking about history, they talk about cycles in history, and they begin using some very interesting numbers drawn from the Bible without even maintaining that these are actually factually true, but rather that they're symbolically important, and that's the reason they're in the Bible.
start setting up parallels between the coming of Christ and what you discover much later to be the coming of some man at the beginning of this century.
And some of the similarities which had been noted by historians before between the history of the Christian church and the history of the Jewish people are very striking.
40-year periods, 300-year periods, and that sort of thing.
The papal captivity in Avignon, or the banishment to Avignon, is sometimes referred to as the Babylonian captivity, and that sort of thing.
And some very interesting parallels.
Probably the most striking part of the lecture series, as far as I was concerned.

And what this does is that by saying that in this century we have a chance that mankind hasn't had for 2,000 years to make changes and to do things, and we've been brought to this point because you're a person who's been selected by God to participate in this process.
And you have gifts and things that mankind needs.
That message is put however explicitly it is present.
It's very powerful.
It's very attractive and also very manipulative.
The church has no qualms about having individual members

They push having individual members develop as strong a relationship as possible with the prospective converts, exhibiting a great deal of interest in them personally, listening for long hours to them talk about themselves if necessary, or do whatever is necessary.
But in general, just try to make them feel loved, make them feel wanted.
And they want to.
It's a natural kind of thing.
It's manipulative, yes, but it's also sincere.
Anyway, by doing that, they often engender a lot of these chapter two feelings, as they talk about, that is to say, feelings of physical attraction.
And then those feelings are engendered, and then the person is made to feel
guilty about those feelings.
And it's another example.
And the fallen nature for the church is expressed in two ways.
One, in being physically attracted to a person of the opposite sex or the same sex as a man.
Or in insubordination.
So those two...
human tendencies are the ones that get to be the target of a lot of very negative feelings and a lot of negative discussion.
Were you encouraged to confess all these guilty feelings to another member?
Yeah, definitely.
As I mentioned before, each member has
his or her own personal leader, they pattern all the relationships on the relationship of Cain and Abel.
That's not to say that they're supposed to kill each other, but rather they examine the story of Cain and Abel for what the problems were.
And the thing was is that they...
believe that Abel was in a position of being closer to God because of reversals caused by the Fallen.
There's no sense going into all this theology, but in any event, that's sort of the source of the story.

And that Cain was responsible to overcome his own feelings of superiority, more experience, being in the firstborn position, overcome all of those natural jealous feelings, and feeling like he was more qualified, all that sort of stuff, and accept Abel's leadership.
and thereby become close to God.
And so, all relationships are established on that basis, and that the person who is the leader is in the able position, and the person who is the follower is in the keen position.
Now, this gets...
There's a great deal of very convoluted discussion and...
Well, Moon will at different times say, you don't know who's in the Cain position.
You don't know who's in the evil position.

Both must act as though they are Cain to try to help overcome some of the natural inequities that come about, as you can imagine, in those kinds of situations where one person is kind of established as being closer to God than the other.
The potential for some pretty ridiculous
overcompensation is observed sometimes in the church.

But since you have an individual who is in that position between you and God, then you are encouraged to confess to them, to tell them all of your feelings, to tell them about your past, about the things you've done wrong.
This gives them a great deal of power over you.
And that is also passed on to their immediate able, that sort of thing, on and on.
The initial doubts that you described about the group, how were those overcome?
And was it a long process?
I don't think they were really... Those doubts were feelings as much as ideas.
I would say that in terms of the ideas being overcome, that was mostly a matter of choice.
And that choice was motivated by my emotional commitment to the people.
Is that if these people are what they say they are and this is what this is, then I need to just simply buckle down and accept this and learn to understand it.
And that's really the approach that the church takes, that doubts and those sorts of things are evidence of individual guilt, guiltiness, sin.
And so one, in the first place, doesn't want to admit it because it's evidence of one's own shortcomings.
And when one does, it's the process of overcoming it.
In terms of the feelings of doubt and stuff, sort of the same thing.
It was sort of a choice to do that.
Although, as I said, the choice was essentially a manipulated choice.
I was deciding on the basis of how wonderful these people were and how wonderful they were to me, which I thought was evidence of this being the right thing.
And didn't realize that there was a structure that had been...
designed to do that very thing, to attract people and get them involved.

But those were still in place when it came to the time that I was confronted with the breakdown of the day-to-day structure that was so important in keeping people in the group, the enforced ritual of
of early rising and meals, work, all that stuff that kept you very busy.
When I was confronted with the breakdown of that, with the incredible pain that my family had gone through because of this, those doubts were still fresh in my mind.
Now that's not to say that I was in the process of doubting the church at that time.
I wasn't.
But I still remembered those feelings and those thoughts that I had.
And I could understand how people could feel that way about the church.
I could understand positions opposed to the church very well.
And essentially for me, leaving the church was a process...
of realizing that my commitment was a manipulated commitment.
And so my break with the church came on the basis of realizing that I did not have an authentic commitment to the church at all, but rather one that was based on... That's Pastor Clark.
That's a fast clock.
Paul, you need to be quiet because this machine is taping everything you're saying.
My commitment was a, as I said, a manipulated one and not one that I had chosen on the basis of this being the best idea.
And the anger that I experienced at realizing that I had been manipulated and been used rather than
making the choice and committing myself to it.
The anger that I felt was the thing that really freed me from that control.
And once I realized that, I knew what all the problems of the church were.
Some former members describe a loss of ability to think rationally during the introduction period.
Would you use that description concerning yourself?
Yeah, I would say, as I said, the introduction period was not an intensive weekend for me like it was for other people.

What was happening to me at that time was that I was at a point of tremendous flux in my own personal life, which made me more liable to make choices on the basis of what felt good and what felt right.
And the thing is, is that I think as growing up as a Christian, I had always, you know, you're taught to look for the gifts of the Spirit and long-sufferingness and love and that sort of thing.
And I wasn't finding that in my friends.
I'll be very frank about that.
The relationships that I had at that time were not terribly satisfying.
And I think that becoming an adult, whether one is involved in the church,
that is, the Christian church or whatever, or not, is a process of learning how to develop good, solid, loving relationships, which is not easy.
Because when it is done by both members choosing to do it and choosing to make a commitment, it's very difficult.
The thing that happens with the church is that the individuals involved with proselytizing
know that that kind of love and affection is what everybody needs and what everybody's looking for.
And so they're willing to give it to you in triple doses during that introductory period and that indoctrination period, but they can't afford to keep giving it afterwards.
So you get lots of lumps of brown sugar during the indoctrination period.
And essentially, that's what you're looking for is evidence that these are good people and that this is a good thing to become involved with.
But those lumps of brown sugar don't continue to come after you join.
You have to work harder and harder to get them.
So yeah, I think a loss of the ability, a loss of the desire and the need for it.
You know, when you're experiencing the kind of love and attention that you've always wanted and really haven't had since you were a child.
then rational evidence is much less important.
And I think anybody who's really familiar with human nature and with people and working with people knows that that's the case.
It's just that we try to be honest with each other as well as loving.
And that's the thing that the Church does not do at all.
They're very conscious of extreme levels of deception.
They call it heavenly deception and they deny that that exists.
Of course they deny it exists.
But, yeah, at the time that if somebody asked them if Sun Myung Moon is the Messiah, they may be honest enough to say, well, what do you think?
But for them to come out and say yes would be against the tenets of the Church, even though that's exactly what they believe.
So I guess in the long run, yes, the answer is yes, that you do experience a loss of ability to think rationally.
Or what I would say is, more than that, loss of the ability to make choices based on rationality, because you're getting this overload of...
of emotional information that I think makes it very difficult to say, well, you know, these are really great people, maybe the most loving people I've ever met.
They obviously love each other very much.
It's a great organization.
A real paradigm of what relationships should be like.
But I think their theology is a mess, so I'm not going to be involved.
That's not the way you decide.
There's a place in...
one of Jesus' prayers that's recorded, where it talks about...
You know, I pray that these people would love each other so that the world may know that I am Christ.
And I think that's what we look for.
We look for love between individuals.
And as Christians, we certainly look for love within the church as evidence that Christ is alive and working among us.
And so when you see that happen, it's hard to say, boy, theology sure is a mess.
I don't think this is real.
Because you don't realize it's not real.
In your opinion then, did you identify more with Moon and his Divine Principle, or with the group and the communal living?
Oh, definitely the latter.
The identification with Moon was predicated on everything else.
Although, he is a very charismatic individual, and when I first observed him, it confirmed a lot of things for me, in the sense that I remember the sense of every motion that he made being very
definite.
He's one of these people who walks through a room and you notice him.
He's aggressive in a sense, but not aggressive in an angular, jerky way.
He's just very deliberate.
And a real natural leader.
There's no doubt about it.
Tremendous charismatic personality.
And also capable of exhibiting
human concern, although you don't know whether that's by choice or by nature.
And it doesn't really matter.
It has the same effect either way.
How do the group dynamics of the Unification Church differ from other groups in society?
Well...
My first inclination is to say there's no comparison.
There's no place in society outside of possibly the army.
But even in the army, there is always a sense that you're going to be out in two years.
Or if it really came down to it, this leader could be subject to court martial or something like that.
There is never a sense in the church that there is any recourse beyond that immediate leader.
With the army, you know that you have, there's a certain set of rules by which everybody lives.
And I suppose in the church there's an element of that too.
But really when it comes down to the one-to-one level, the person who is the immediate leader has a great deal of authority over the individual member.
Thank you.
Everything about one's life, one is responsible to share with one's able.
One's dreams, one's fantasies.
Moon determines who you're going to marry.
The church administration decides primarily what kind of work you're going to be involved with.
I experienced times in the church where we essentially were told to give up all of our personal possessions.
I was told to give away all of my clothes and only wear clothes that had been given to me by other members.
I was told to cut my hair and shave my beard when I first joined, and I did it basically without question.
But realizing that this becoming like a child, in a sense, was the ideal.
And this ideal of becoming like a child
in accepting unquestionably any directive which comes to you is a real ideal within the church.
Now, of course, that breaks down sometimes.
But it is...
an extreme level of commitment.
And it's not just the people who decide to become monks or become priests.
It's every individual.
The lack of personal space is, I think, an extreme one.
While in many

religious orders one is encouraged to have a personal meditative life and things like that in the church you're encouraged to have personal prayers and stuff like that you're told about how they're supposed to be and hardly given enough time to do it on top of that it's really it's extremely intense and i think that it's possible i was reading in one book

that talked about thought reform in China, by Robert Lifton, Thought Reform and Psychology of Totalism, I think, how it is possible with certain individuals to have tremendous periods of personal growth
within that kind of intensity of environment.
And some people do actually opt for that.
You know, monasticism is that kind of a tradition.

The thing that happens with the Unification Church is that rather than taking a long time to prepare and everybody trying to discourage you and make sure that this is exactly what you want to do and you know what you're getting yourself into,
They deliberately prevent you from finding what you're into, but by the use of emotional pressure, try to persuade you to get into it and make you feel guilty for trying to get out.
So the manipulation happens at an extremely personal level, the most personal level as possible.
I felt horrible guilt about having wet dreams.
And, well, the sexual repression in the group was extreme.
And for a young man 19 years old, something's just going to happen.
That's all there is to it.
But I felt tremendous guilt because I thought that this was...
